member.name: T:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.AmazonAugmentedAIRuntimeDefaultConfiguration
member.summary: Configuration for accessing Amazon AugmentedAIRuntime service

member.name: M:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.AmazonAugmentedAIRuntimeDefaultConfiguration.GetAllConfigurations
member.summary: Collection of all s supported by AugmentedAIRuntime

summary.p: The STANDARD mode provides the latest recommended default values that should be safe to run in most scenarios
Note that the default values vended from this mode might change as best practices may evolve. As a result, it is encouraged to perform tests when upgrading the SDK
The IN_REGION mode builds on the standard mode and includes optimization tailored for applications which call AWS services from within the same AWS region
Note that the default values vended from this mode might change as best practices may evolve. As a result, it is encouraged to perform tests when upgrading the SDK
The CROSS_REGION mode builds on the standard mode and includes optimization tailored for applications which call AWS services in a different region
Note that the default values vended from this mode might change as best practices may evolve. As a result, it is encouraged to perform tests when upgrading the SDK
The MOBILE mode builds on the standard mode and includes optimization tailored for mobile applications
Note that the default values vended from this mode might change as best practices may evolve. As a result, it is encouraged to perform tests when upgrading the SDK
The AUTO mode is an experimental mode that builds on the standard mode. The SDK will attempt to discover the execution environment to determine the appropriate settings automatically.

Note that the auto detection is heuristics-based and does not guarantee 100% accuracy. STANDARD mode will be used if the execution environment cannot be determined. The auto detection might query EC2 Instance Metadata service, which might introduce latency. Therefore we recommend choosing an explicit defaults_mode instead if startup latency is critical to your application
The LEGACY mode provides default settings that vary per SDK and were used prior to establishment of defaults_mode

member.name: T:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Endpoints.AugmentedAIRuntimeEndpointParameters
member.summary: Contains parameters used for resolving AugmentedAIRuntime endpoints Parameters can be sourced from client config and service operations Used by internal AugmentedAIRuntimeEndpointProvider and AugmentedAIRuntimeEndpointResolver Can be used by custom EndpointProvider, see ClientConfig.EndpointProvider

member.name: T:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Internal.AmazonAugmentedAIRuntimeEndpointProvider
member.summary: Amazon AugmentedAIRuntime endpoint provider. Resolves endpoint for given set of AugmentedAIRuntimeEndpointParameters. Can throw AmazonClientException if endpoint resolution is unsuccessful.

member.name: M:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Internal.AmazonAugmentedAIRuntimeEndpointProvider.ResolveEndpoint(Amazon.Runtime.Endpoints.EndpointParameters)
member.summary: Resolve endpoint for AugmentedAIRuntimeEndpointParameters

member.name: T:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Internal.AmazonAugmentedAIRuntimeEndpointResolver
member.summary: Amazon AugmentedAIRuntime endpoint resolver. Custom PipelineHandler responsible for resolving endpoint and setting authentication parameters for AugmentedAIRuntime service requests. Collects values for AugmentedAIRuntimeEndpointParameters and then tries to resolve endpoint by calling ResolveEndpoint method on GlobalEndpoints.Provider if present, otherwise uses AugmentedAIRuntimeEndpointProvider. Responsible for setting authentication and http headers provided by resolved endpoint.

member.name: T:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.ConflictException
member.summary: Your request has the same name as another active human loop but has different input data. You cannot start two human loops with the same name and different input data.

member.name: T:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.DeleteHumanLoopRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the DeleteHumanLoop operation. Deletes the specified human loop for a flow definition.
If the human loop was deleted, this operation will return a ResourceNotFoundException.

member.name: P:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.DeleteHumanLoopRequest.HumanLoopName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property HumanLoopName.
The name of the human loop that you want to delete.

member.name: T:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.DeleteHumanLoopResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the DeleteHumanLoop operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.DescribeHumanLoopRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the DescribeHumanLoop operation. Returns information about the specified human loop. If the human loop was deleted, this operation will return a ResourceNotFoundException error.

member.name: P:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.DescribeHumanLoopRequest.HumanLoopName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property HumanLoopName.
The name of the human loop that you want information about.

member.name: T:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.DescribeHumanLoopResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the DescribeHumanLoop operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.DescribeHumanLoopResponse.CreationTime
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property CreationTime.
The creation time when Amazon Augmented AI created the human loop.

member.name: P:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.DescribeHumanLoopResponse.FailureCode
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property FailureCode.
A failure code that identifies the type of failure.
Possible values: ValidationError, Expired, InternalError

member.name: P:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.DescribeHumanLoopResponse.FailureReason
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property FailureReason.
The reason why a human loop failed. The failure reason is returned when the status of the human loop is Failed.

member.name: P:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.DescribeHumanLoopResponse.FlowDefinitionArn
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property FlowDefinitionArn.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the flow definition.

member.name: P:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.DescribeHumanLoopResponse.HumanLoopArn
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property HumanLoopArn.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the human loop.

member.name: P:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.DescribeHumanLoopResponse.HumanLoopName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property HumanLoopName.
The name of the human loop. The name must be lowercase, unique within the Region in your account, and can have up to 63 characters. Valid characters: a-z, 0-9, and - (hyphen).

member.name: P:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.DescribeHumanLoopResponse.HumanLoopOutput
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property HumanLoopOutput.
An object that contains information about the output of the human loop.

member.name: P:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.DescribeHumanLoopResponse.HumanLoopStatus
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property HumanLoopStatus.
The status of the human loop.

member.name: T:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.HumanLoopDataAttributes
member.summary: Attributes of the data specified by the customer. Use these to describe the data to be labeled.

member.name: P:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.HumanLoopDataAttributes.ContentClassifiers
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ContentClassifiers.
Declares that your content is free of personally identifiable information or adult content.
Amazon SageMaker can restrict the Amazon Mechanical Turk workers who can view your task based on this information.

member.name: T:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.HumanLoopInput
member.summary: An object containing the human loop input in JSON format.

member.name: P:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.HumanLoopInput.InputContent
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property InputContent.
Serialized input from the human loop. The input must be a string representation of a file in JSON format.

member.name: T:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.HumanLoopOutput
member.summary: Information about where the human output will be stored.

member.name: P:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.HumanLoopOutput.OutputS3Uri
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property OutputS3Uri.
The location of the Amazon S3 object where Amazon Augmented AI stores your human loop output.

member.name: T:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.HumanLoopSummary
member.summary: Summary information about the human loop.

member.name: P:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.HumanLoopSummary.CreationTime
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property CreationTime.
When Amazon Augmented AI created the human loop.

member.name: P:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.HumanLoopSummary.FailureReason
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property FailureReason.
The reason why the human loop failed. A failure reason is returned when the status of the human loop is Failed.

member.name: P:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.HumanLoopSummary.FlowDefinitionArn
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property FlowDefinitionArn.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the flow definition used to configure the human loop.

member.name: P:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.HumanLoopSummary.HumanLoopName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property HumanLoopName.
The name of the human loop.

member.name: P:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.HumanLoopSummary.HumanLoopStatus
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property HumanLoopStatus.
The status of the human loop.

member.name: T:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.ListHumanLoopsRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the ListHumanLoops operation. Returns information about human loops, given the specified parameters. If a human loop was deleted, it will not be included.

member.name: P:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.ListHumanLoopsRequest.CreationTimeAfter
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property CreationTimeAfter.
(Optional) The timestamp of the date when you want the human loops to begin in ISO 8601 format. For example, 2020-02-24.

member.name: P:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.ListHumanLoopsRequest.CreationTimeBefore
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property CreationTimeBefore.
(Optional) The timestamp of the date before which you want the human loops to begin in ISO 8601 format. For example, 2020-02-24.

member.name: P:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.ListHumanLoopsRequest.FlowDefinitionArn
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property FlowDefinitionArn.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of a flow definition.

member.name: P:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.ListHumanLoopsRequest.MaxResults
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MaxResults.
The total number of items to return. If the total number of available items is more than the value specified in MaxResults, then a NextToken is returned in the output. You can use this token to display the next page of results.

member.name: P:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.ListHumanLoopsRequest.NextToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NextToken.
A token to display the next page of results.

member.name: P:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.ListHumanLoopsRequest.SortOrder
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SortOrder.
Optional. The order for displaying results. Valid values: Ascending and Descending.

member.name: T:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.ListHumanLoopsResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the ListHumanLoops operation.

member.summary:

An array of objects that contain information about the human loops.

member.name: P:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.Model.ListHumanLoopsResponse.NextToken

member.name: T:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.AmazonAugmentedAIRuntimeClient
member.summary:
Implementation for accessing AugmentedAIRuntime
Amazon Augmented AI (Amazon A2I) adds the benefit of human judgment to any machine learning application. When an AI application can't evaluate data with a high degree of confidence, human reviewers can take over. This human review is called a human review workflow. To create and start a human review workflow, you need three resources: a worker task template, a flow definition, and a human loop.
For information about these resources and prerequisites for using Amazon A2I, see Get Started with Amazon Augmented AI in the Amazon SageMaker Developer Guide.
This API reference includes information about API actions and data types that you can use to interact with Amazon A2I programmatically. Use this guide to:
Start a human loop with the StartHumanLoop operation when using Amazon A2I with a custom task type. To learn more about the difference between custom and built-in task types, see Use Task Types . To learn how to start a human loop using this API, see Create and Start a Human Loop for a Custom Task Type in the Amazon SageMaker Developer Guide.
Manage your human loops. You can list all human loops that you have created, describe individual human loops, and stop and delete human loops. To learn more, see Monitor and Manage Your Human Loop in the Amazon SageMaker Developer Guide.
Amazon A2I integrates APIs from various AWS services to create and start human review workflows for those services. To learn how Amazon A2I uses these APIs, see Use APIs in Amazon A2I in the Amazon SageMaker Developer Guide.

member.name: M:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.AmazonAugmentedAIRuntimeClient.#ctor
member.summary:
Constructs AmazonAugmentedAIRuntimeClient with the credentials loaded from the application's default configuration, and if unsuccessful from the Instance Profile service on an EC2 instance.
Example App.config with credentials set.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <configuration> <appSettings> <add key="AWSProfileName" value="AWS Default"/> </appSettings> </configuration>

member.name: M:Amazon.AugmentedAIRuntime.AmazonAugmentedAIRuntimeClient.#ctor(Amazon.RegionEndpoint)
member.summary:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <configuration> <appSettings> <add key="AWSProfileName" value="AWS Default"/> </appSettings> </configuration>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <configuration> <appSettings> <add key="AWSProfileName" value="AWS Default"/> </appSettings> </configuration>

Amazon Augmented AI (Amazon A2I) adds the benefit of human judgment to any machine learning application. When an AI application can't evaluate data with a high degree of confidence, human reviewers can take over. This human review is called a human review workflow. To create and start a human review workflow, you need three resources: a worker task template, a flow definition, and a human loop.
For information about these resources and prerequisites for using Amazon A2I, see Get Started with Amazon Augmented AI in the Amazon SageMaker Developer Guide.
